tone_of_voice.name: Radically Human
tone_of_voice.tagline: Be true. Be you. Be authentic and honest. Always.

core_philosophy.description: Building authentic and honest connections through language that brings people together, not distances them.
core_philosophy.foundation: People are our purpose. We believe in partners, not clients. Trust is the foundation of any relationship.

brand_values.description: We embrace people with different points of view, from different backgrounds. And we think and work as one team.
We say what we mean, and we do what we say. We hold ourselves to the highest standards. And we make it safe for people to speak out when they see something wrong.
We are insatiably curious, always learning new things. And we actively help our colleagues grow and develop too, with mentoring and support.
We never settle for the status quo. We always strive to be better today than we were yesterday, and do our best for our clients, colleagues, and shareholders.

six_simple_rules.title: Start with why
six_simple_rules.description: That's either the most important or exciting point you're trying to make to benefit your reader.
six_simple_rules.guidance: Focus on why the reader should care, not just what we do or how we do it. Challenge every statement with 'why?' until no more 'whys?' need to be asked.

six_simple_rules.title: Tell it like it is
six_simple_rules.description: And if there's a negative thing to say, talk about how you'll help people overcome it.
six_simple_rules.guidance: Start with the positive. It takes courage to tell partners what they need to know, not just what they want to hear.

six_simple_rules.title: Say what you think
six_simple_rules.description: And back it up with our knowledge and research.
six_simple_rules.guidance: Give opinions (not just observations) and recommendations (not only options). Use stories, relationships, and facts and figures to back up your points.

six_simple_rules.title: Use everyday language
six_simple_rules.description: Would an intelligent person from outside our industry understand?
six_simple_rules.guidance: Drop consultant-speak and jargon. Use normal words. Make language accessible to everyone.

six_simple_rules.title: Make it personal
six_simple_rules.guidance: Try to say 'you' and 'yours' more than you say 'we' and 'ours'. Aim for a ratio of 2:1.

six_simple_rules.title: Give them a clear call to action
six_simple_rules.description: What do you want your reader to do?
six_simple_rules.guidance: Be clear about the next step and why they should care.

write_like_you_speak.description: Writing like you speak makes you sound more human and empathetic.

methods.technique: Say you, we, us, and I
methods.guidance: Personal pronouns add a personal touch. Say 'you,' not 'partners'; 'we' and 'us' not 'Korn Ferry.' Aim for a ratio of 2:1 (you:we).
If a noun ends in -ance/-ence, -ing, -tion/-sion, and -ment, you can usually turn it into a verb.

examples.before: The utilization of technology is widespread.
examples.after: We use a lot of technology.

examples.before: The management of people is important.
examples.after: How you manage your people is important.

methods.guidance: Active sentences make it clear who is doing what and take responsibility for what's happened.

be_knowledgeable.description: Showcase our expert advice, insight, and ability to apply what we know.
methods: Say what you think - give opinions and recommendations at the start
Say why you think it - use stories, relationships, and facts/figures
Say it straight - no hedging, no caveats

be_honest.description: Tell it like it is, but start with the positive.
methods: Start with the positive to open people up rather than make them defensive
Cut it down - SCAMPI (Succinct Copy Always Makes a Positive Impact)
Vary the pace - mix sentence lengths
Use normal words, not formal ones
Use metaphors to explain complicated ideas

punctuation.oxford_comma: Use when it helps avoid confusion

em_dash.usage: Use longest dash (â€”) without spaces on either side
em_dash.purpose: Separate non-essential information, can replace commas or parentheses

punctuation.hyphens: Only use as part of hyphenated compounds, not as punctuation

bullet_lists.short_items: No punctuation on each point, colon to introduce, full stop at end
bullet_lists.stem_statements: Only full stop at end of bullets, don't capitalize first word

contractions.usage: Use in writing as you would in speech

style_preferences.language: American English (default), UK English for UK-specific content
style_preferences.compound_words: Hyphenate compound adjectives to avoid confusion

acronyms.first_use: Spell out with acronym in brackets
acronyms.common_acronyms: No need to spell out if audience will understand

style_preferences.ampersand: Only use in abbreviations (D&I) or company names (AT&T), not as replacement for 'and'

bullets: Start each with same type of word
Stick to four or five maximum

types: Summaries (e.g., 'We need to step in now')

words_to_avoid.avoid_jargon: touch base, align, bandwidth, leverage, digitally transformative

influences.contribution: Start with Why - standing out from the crowd
Resonant leadership - starting with the positive emotional attractor
Cognitive ease - making writing as clear as possible so readers don't strain

key_principles_summary: Simple, honest, clear, consistent is always better than long words and technical concepts
Use language to come together, not to distance
Don't hide behind language to sound more intelligent
Don't build walls of words that people have to climb over
Listen as much as we talk
Give everyone a platform to speak, whatever their background
The truth is: simple, honest, clear, consistent is always better
